author: pipermerriam
content: What would someone need to show you to accept that the total size of the state is a problem?

author: cf0009
content: Gas prices were high a month ago. Now they are just ridiculous. That's also a factor

author: pipermerriam
content: Actually, can I take a different tact on this...  you want the limit pushed to 40MM...  this probably wouldn't be likely to take the network down, but it also isn't likely to have a meaningful effect on gas prices in anything beyond the short term.  It is my opinion that blocks are likely to quickly go back to being full and gas prices will start going back up.  Is this inline with your view of the world?

author: cf0009
content: Yes, that's an ambitious take. I like it

author: pipermerriam
content: ok, second part...  anything that reduces gas prices should also increase adoption  which increases demand, which accelerates state growth and drives gas prices back up.  do we agree on this?

author: cf0009
content: Yes, demand is a good thing

author: pipermerriam
content: So the only way to meaningfully decrease gas prices beyond the short term by altering the gas limit is to outpace demand with the gas limit.  I don't know how high that would have to be, but I think it would have to be much higher than 40MM to outpace demand and adoption...  do you agree/disagree with this?

author: pipermerriam
content: (and every time we increase the limit, we accelerate the rate of state growth)

author: cf0009
content: A small raise now and the merge later on will help buy time. It means more time for L2's. More time for state management. All of this

author: pipermerriam
content: Ok, but I'm asking you to look at this from the perspective of "caring for the protocol" which also means "caring for the clients that run the protocol".  So what you are proposing is a short term gain that won't last at the cost of making the problem of state size larger.  And that's something that many of us aren't willing to do because the trade-off isn't worth the cost.

author: pipermerriam
content: Can you see that line of thinking? The line of reasoning that leads me (and some others) to see the idea of raising the gas limit as just making one problem worse but not having a meaningful effect on the problem it's aimed at fixing.

author: cf0009
content: Yes, I do. As I said earlier "fair enough"

author: cf0009
content: This isn't sharding. This is not huge scalability gains. This is a quick fix to a hot problem . Something to help users until the real fixes come in (that will take years)

author: pipermerriam
content: Yeah, it's an unfortunate situation.  It'd be really nice if we could scale now because there's certainly more demand than there is block space.

author: pipermerriam
content: I don't find your line of reasoning convincing. There's already a lot of companies with plenty of resources and vested interests using ethereum.

author: gwintery
content: Companies are also profit oriented, so it does not necessarily mean they care about the long term viability of Ethereum. It may be that they will jump ship as long as a better solution/platform shows up.

author: gwintery
content: in the micro scale, we can see projects jumping ship to other platforms once they see an opportunity to do so

author: treyzania
content: ^ corporations have no interest in long term sustainability if it comes at the cost of short term profits

author: treyzania
content:
okay let me clarify that:
s/corporations/corporations of sufficient scale in general/

author: treyzania
content: there's plenty of evidence in the real world to show that large corporations that *do* consider long term sustainability are the rare exceptions to the rule

author: treyzania
content: that applies to cryptocurrencies as it does to everything else
